claim: Optimize AI for real-world outcomes using a Value Matrix, not raw accuracy.
rationale: Accuracy alone yields timid AI; cost/benefit of TP/TN/FP/FN determines optimal model behavior.

claim: Avoid direct AI-vs-expert competition; reframe AI as assistant to reduce resistance.
rationale: Head-to-head with experts triggers pride/suspicion; assistant framing drives adoption.

claim: Assume AI is biased; actively prompt for diversity and seek what's missing.
rationale: Generative models reflect data bias; slight prompt tweaks can broaden representation.

claim: AI-inclusive design is continuous iteration of UI, model, and data together—not sequential.
rationale: AI output must be experienced live; traditional sequential UX misses interactive AI realities.

claim: RITE (Rapid Iterative Testing and Evaluation) outperforms traditional usability testing for AI products.
rationale: RITE prototypes invite change and co-creation; tests produce solutions, not just reports.

claim: Storyboards expose gaps and misframed AI use cases better than text alone.
rationale: Visualizing reveals impracticality early (e.g., 'AI therapist' vs 'AI helping hand').

claim: Digital twin modeling with cross-functional team clarifies what to include/omit in AI models.
rationale: Multiple perspectives surface inputs, outputs, missing data, and ethics; discussion delivers value.

claim: The best AI is no AI if simple solutions work; start with deterministic or 'boring AI' baselines.
rationale: AI adds cost/complexity/unpredictability; resilient core should withstand AI errors.

claim: AI is too important to leave to data scientists alone; UX must shape business and human impact.
rationale: Value Matrix translates tech metrics to business/human terms; TSA accuracy example shows tech alone is insufficient.

claim: Five failure ways: replace experts; skip cost/benefit; no data; answer convenient DS questions; no user research.
rationale: Boiling spaghetti (AGRU) failed all five: wrong question, missing data, no SME context.

claim: Replacing user studies with 'synthetic users' builds products for robots, not people.
rationale: LLMs mimic typical behavior and miss diversity; Baymard found ~80% error in ChatGPT UX audits.

claim: Algorithmic bias in dashboards/search has societal impact; design is not neutral.
rationale: Sorting/visibility choices shape perceptions (e.g., political bubbles, missing candidates).

claim: No data is truly private once in an LLM; guardrails can be bypassed via prompt engineering.
rationale: Roleplay/academic framing can exfiltrate data; privacy must be a design constraint.

claim: Value Matrix: monetize confusion matrix by assigning costs/benefits to TP/TN/FP/FN to choose model aggressiveness.
rationale: Different cost assumptions invert which model is best; aligns AI to business ROI.

claim: Seven LLM interaction patterns: Restating, Auto-Complete, Talk-Back, Initial Suggestions, Next Steps, Regen Tweaks, Guardrails.
rationale: Each pattern addresses specific interaction needs (clarity, prevention, reasoning, follow-up, creativity, safety).

claim: Copilot real estate: Side Panel (localized), Full Page (deep analysis), Large Overlay (avoid; obscures). Match scope to task.
rationale: UI placement must fit task importance; overlays hurt usability; full pages for complex, side panels for context.

claim: AI-first IA: Analysis Overview (LLM-driven), Category Analysis, LLM Search, Item Detail with contextual ask bar, Maintenance with AI troubleshooting.
rationale: AI-first apps still need IA; dynamic canvases + traditional IA to tell the user’s story.

claim: Four anomaly types need different UX: Point, Change Point, Contextual, Curve Shape.
rationale: Thresholds/sensitivity depend on anomaly type; work with experts to configure and act.

claim: Red flags: AI costs exceed expert; wrong-guess cost exceeds right-guess benefit; no data; custom model per install.
rationale: Each red flag can doom a project; multiple flags guarantee failure.

claim: UX skills rising in value: facilitation, ethnography, observation, vision prototyping, strategy augmentation.
rationale: AI can’t replace contextual understanding or in-room observation; human skills will command premium.

claim: Pascal Motors Value Matrix: accuracy-optimized AI missed problems; aggressive model delivered 158% more revenue.
rationale: Business-ROI optimization reversed which model was 'best' vs accuracy-only view.

claim: Sumo Logic Copilot success: strong use case, clear vision, full-screen UI, autocomplete, next-steps suggestions.
rationale: Copilot success required more than chat—contextual UI and learning from journeys.

claim: Precision irrigation reframed from 'tell farmers when to water' to 'where to use less without hurting yield'—assistant framing drove adoption.
rationale: Reframe from replacement to assistant aligned with real farmer concerns (water, regs, climate).

claim: LLM search solves 'Mysteries not scary' query with custom facets vs. traditional hodgepodge results.
rationale: LLMs handle negation/fuzzy queries, delivering well-formed, custom results users will soon expect.
